Statement of Purpose
Application for Precog Research Lab
When Professor PK first introduced us to Precog towards the end of the DNA course, I felt
an immediate and intuitive inclination toward the lab—something that was difficult to explain
at the time. At that point, I did not fully understand what the Honors program was, what
Precog specifically worked on, or the research areas it focused on. Yet, the way Precog was presented—as a space that values depth, rigor, and exploration of challenging problems—resonated
strongly with me.
Motivated by this initial curiosity, I began learning more about Precog by interacting with
seniors and exploring the lab’s research themes in detail. As I read about the problems Precog
focuses on and its broader research philosophy, my interest became more concrete. I found
myself drawn to research that emphasizes understanding, reliability, and reasoning in learningbased systems rather than treating models as opaque black boxes. Through this process, I
identified the areas I am most interested in working on in depth: interpretability, natural
language processing, and robustness.
One of the main reasons I wish to work with Precog is its emphasis on interpretability as a core
research objective. As learning-based systems are increasingly deployed in complex and sequential decision-making settings, understanding why a system behaves in a certain way becomes
crucial. I am interested in methods that uncover the structure of learned representations, provide insight into decision-making processes, and allow systematic analysis of failures. Precog’s
approach to interpretability, grounded in reasoning rather than superficial explanations, aligns
closely with how I want to approach research.
I am also interested in natural language processing, particularly beyond conventional textcentric tasks. I am fascinated by the idea of language as a medium for abstraction, instruction,
and explanation in intelligent systems. I see strong potential in using language to improve
transparency and alignment by enabling humans to specify intent, constraints, or reasoning in
a more natural form. This view of NLP as an interface to reasoning and decision-making closely
matches Precog’s research direction.
Robustness forms the third pillar of my interest. Real-world systems must operate under noise,
uncertainty, and distribution shifts, and I am keen to study how learning-based models behave when assumptions break. I am particularly interested in designing systems that degrade
gracefully and can be analyzed and debugged under failure. Precog’s focus on robustness as a
foundational concern, rather than an afterthought, strongly resonates with my own perspective.
My academic and project experiences have trained me to think carefully about problem struc1
ture, assumptions, and edge cases. I am comfortable working with incomplete specifications
and iteratively refining systems based on observed behavior. Rather than optimizing solely for
performance metrics, I focus on understanding underlying mechanisms and failure modes, which
has naturally shaped my interest in interpretability and robustness.
At Precog, I hope to work on problems that combine interpretability, language, and robustness
in learning-based decision systems. I am eager to engage deeply with challenging research
problems, learn from the group, and contribute meaningfully to Precog’s efforts in building
intelligent systems that are reliable, interpretable, and grounded in reasoning.
I believe that I am definitely not the best candidate but will always try to achieve it by my
persistence, perseverance, and patience towards my goal. Of course, nothing is perfect in
nature, including nature itself; evolution, for instance, works through countless small failures
before producing something robust enough to survive. But I will always try to improve myself,
and the only person I will try to compete with is the ME yesterday. If anyone could do better
than me today, that will only be ME tomorrow. I focus on improving the process rather than
worrying too much about anything, because ultimately our output is just the by-product of the
process and efforts we put in.
